docs.abstract: A nonprofit and a mayor are bringing nutritional progress to a city once ranked low on the real-food chain.
docs.lead_paragraph: Foodwise, among the most progressive cities in the country right now is Philadelphia, where the alliance of a forward-thinking mayor and a 19-year-old non-profit is moving things forward. Within a year or two, Philly might be funding better access to real food for its poorest citizens by taxing soda. And if you accept the notion that childhood obesity and the accompanying Type 2 diabetes are big problems, and you're aware that soda is a major cause, you'll agree that's a huge step in the right direction.
docs.snippet: A nonprofit and a mayor are bringing nutritional progress to a city once ranked low on the real-food chain.

headline.seo: Does the Mediterranean Diet Even Exist?
headline.main: Does the Mediterranean Diet Even Exist?

docs.lead_paragraph: Olive oil, whole grains, fish, fruits and vegetables are not what people in the region are eating.

headline.seo: F.D.A. Rule on Calorie Counting to Exempt Movie Theaters
headline.print_headline: Counting the Calories, Except at the Movies
headline.main: Calorie-Counting Rule to Leave Out Movie Theaters

docs.lead_paragraph: After opposition from the movie industry, theaters were exempted from a proposed rule that would require restaurants to post calorie counts next to menu items.
docs.snippet: After opposition from the movie industry, theaters were exempted from a proposed rule that would require restaurants to post calorie counts next to menu items.

headline.seo: Health Issues Facing Gays Need More Research, Panel Says
headline.print_headline: U.S. Panel Suggests Research Into Causes and Prevalence of Health Issues Facing Gays
headline.main: U.S. Panel Suggests Research Into Causes and Prevalence of Health Issues Facing Gays

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Academy of Sciences proposed research into understand why gays are more likely to have certain chronic conditions like obesity, depression, cancer and heart disease.
docs.snippet: The National Academy of Sciences proposed research into understand why gays are more likely to have certain chronic conditions like obesity, depression, cancer and heart disease.
